title: South Africa's De Klerk and Mapimpi break Japanese resistance and hearts
text:
Mapimpi and and De Klerk were integral to Japan’s downfall (Picture: Getty)

Makazole Mapimpi scored twice as South Africa ended Japan’s run in the Rugby World Cup with a 26-3 victory in their quarter-final clash.

Faf de Klerk ran the show from scrum-half but after Mapimpi opened the scoring early on, South Africa struggled to find a way past a belligerent Japanese defensive line.

Tendai Mtawarira – the Beast – was lucky to avoid a red card after a tip-tackle only earned him a yellow but Japan were unable to capitalise and eventually the South African superiority and physicality told in the second half as the boot of De Klerk and Handre Pollard suffocated a team who have brought so much fresh air to the tournament.

Japan suffered their first defeat of the tournament as they crashed out (Picture: Getty)

South Africa’s early goal will have been to quieten the crowd and let the outnumbered green jerseys in the seats make themselves heard and they achieved as much when Mapimpi went over in the left corner after a powerful South African scrum.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The conversion leaked wide of the far post though and South Africa would not score another point in the first half, as much by virtue of their own handling errors as the Japanese defence.

With ball in hand, Japan were mesmerising and bold, as they have been all tournament, not afraid to throw the ball wide quickly to try break the line speed of the Springboks.

South Africa might have been down to 14 men for the last 70 minutes though had referee Wayne Barnes taken a second look at Mtawarira’s tip-tackle, but his instantaneous decision was a yellow card – not a red one.

But a Yu Tamura penalty was all the Cherry Blossoms could muster with their advantage, although even that three-point score was greeted with a noise that was louder than most tries.

For all their possession and territory though – at one point after half an hour Japan had enjoyed 80 per cent of the ball – the points would not come.

Japan have been the World Cup’s dark horses (Picture: Getty)

South Africa went back to basics after half-time as De Klerk kicked the ball more and they showed the set-piece strength that has made them so feared in the Rugby Championship.

Japan found it almost impossible to get out of their half, the rolling maul became so effective that clearing kicks were kept infield, making exit strategy ineffective.

Advertisement

Advertisement

And it was the rolling maul that produced South Africa’s second try, starting on the 10-metre line and making it inside the Japanese 22 before De Klerk – who else? – was on hand to finish it off.

South Africa eventually broke Japan’s resistance (Picture: Getty)

Mapimpi added a third as Japan’s discipline started to fall apart and Pollard punished them from the kicking tee, but the crowd were loud and proud to the end.

Japan’s World Cup journey is over but it will not be quickly forgotten. In four more years’ time, who knows what levels they could reach.

description: Makazole Mapimpi scored twice as South Africa ended Japan's run in the Rugby World Cup with a 26-3 victory in their quarter-final clash.
